Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2015 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Olga Turanova is "Analysis of Nonlinear Partial Differential Equations." The host institution for the fellowship is University of California-Los Angeles, and the sponsoring scientist is Dr. Inwon Kim.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The major goal of this project was to study nonlinear and nonlocal partial differential equations (PDEs), particularly ones that describe physical or biological systems. One avenue of research concerned nonlocal reaction-diffusion equations arising from ecology. The results obtained by the PI and her collaborators settle an open question concerning an equation of this type, the so-called cane toads equation. Another research direction concerned problems of free boundary type. Here, the PI and her postdoctoral mentor obtained results concerning a PDE model of the growth of cancer tumors. The PI also used  tools from PDEs to develop algorithms for robotic swarming. Several publications have come out of this work (two have appeared in print, one has been accepted for publication, and one is a preprint). Moreover, all three projects have opened interesting possibilities for future research that the PI plans to pursue.

The PI supervised a group of six undergraduate students in an REU project, and several of the publications resulting from this project are joint with the students. Three of the students, including two women, are currently pursuing graduate study. In addition, the PI engaged in several public outreach activities, such as an interactive event meant to interest Los Angeles middle school girls in STEM.


 


Last Modified: 10/15/2019
Modified by: Olga Turanova
